At all times during the Term without cost to Owner, Operator shall maintain in force the following insurance, which insurance shall not be subject to cancellation, termination or other material adverse changes unless the insurer delivers to Owner written notice of the cancellation, termination or change at least thirty (30) days in advance of the effective date of the cancellation, termination or material adverse change:
(a) Worker's Compensation Insurance as required by the laws of the state where Operator's facilities are located;
(b) Employer's liability insurance with limits not less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000); and
(c) Commercial General Liability Insurance, including bodily injury and property damage liability including premises operations, contractual liability endorsements, products liability and completed operations with limits not less than Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000). Operator shall cause Owner (and such additional parties as Owner designates in writing) to be named additional insured(s), must be written as primary policy not contributing to or in excess of any policies carried by the Owner, and each contain a waiver of subrogation endorsement, in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the Owner, in favor of the Owner.
perturbation.changed_text:
At all times during the Term without cost to Owner, Operator shall maintain in force the following insurance:
(a) Worker's Compensation Insurance;
(b) Employer's liability insurance; and
(c) Commercial General Liability Insurance. Operator may name Owner as an additional insured.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the requirement for specific insurance limits (One Million Dollars for Employer's Liability and Five Million Dollars for Commercial General Liability) and the requirement for advance notice of cancellation/termination/changes, as well as the waiver of subrogation endorsement, the contract fails to ensure adequate coverage for potential liabilities, potentially violating Delaware's insurance regulations for commercial operations. Furthermore, the clause stating it should be written as primary policy not contributing to or in excess of any policies carried by the Owner is removed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware's insurance regulations for commercial operations (specific statutes vary based on industry and risk assessment but generally require adequate coverage for potential liabilities).

perturbation.original_text: Section 2.16 Performance Standards. For the purpose of this Agreement, the Operator shall perform under this Agreement in accordance and consistent with each of the following (unless the context requires otherwise): (A) permitted plans and specifications applicable to each Facility; (B) the manufacturer's recommendations with respect to all equipment and all maintenance and operating manuals or service agreements, whenever furnished or entered into, including any subsequent amendments or replacements thereof, issued by the manufacturer, provided they are consistent with generally accepted practices in the fuel cell industry; (C) the requirements of all applicable insurance policies; (D) preserving all rights to any incentive payments, warranties, indemnities or other rights or remedies, and enforcing or assisting with the enforcement of the applicable warranties, making or assisting in making all claims with respect to all insurance policies; (E) all Legal Requirements and Permits/Governmental Approvals, (F) the PJM Agreements and the DPL Agreements; (G) any applicable provisions of the Site Leases, including any landlord rules and regulations, and (H) Prudent Electrical Practices (collectively, the "Performance Standards"); provided, however, that meeting these requirements shall not relieve Operator of its other obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 2.16 Performance Standards. For the purpose of this Agreement, the Operator shall perform under this Agreement in accordance and consistent with each of the following (unless the context requires otherwise): (A) permitted plans and specifications applicable to each Facility; (B) the manufacturer's recommendations with respect to all equipment and all maintenance and operating manuals or service agreements, whenever furnished or entered into, including any subsequent amendments or replacements thereof, issued by the manufacturer, provided they are consistent with generally accepted practices in the fuel cell industry; (C) the requirements of all applicable insurance policies; (D) preserving all rights to any incentive payments, warranties, indemnities or other rights or remedies, and enforcing or assisting with the enforcement of the applicable warranties, making or assisting in making all claims with respect to all insurance policies; (G) any applicable provisions of the Site Leases, including any landlord rules and regulations (collectively, the "Performance Standards"); provided, however, that meeting these requirements shall not relieve Operator of its other obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Removing clauses (E), (F), and (H) removes the operator's obligation to adhere to 'all Legal Requirements and Permits/Governmental Approvals', the 'PJM Agreements and the DPL Agreements', and 'Prudent Electrical Practices'. This omission introduces a legal risk as the operator is no longer explicitly bound to comply with relevant laws, permits, grid agreements, and industry standards, potentially violating Delaware regulations regarding energy facility operation and safety.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware regulations regarding energy facility operation and safety (specific statutes vary but generally require compliance with applicable laws, permits, grid agreements, and industry standards).

perturbation.original_text: Section 9.6 Governing Law, Jurisdiction, Venue. THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE GOVERNED BY AND INTERPRETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK WITHOUT REGARD TO CONFLICTS OF LAW PRINCIPLES (OTHER THAN SECTION 5-1401 OF THE NEW YORK GENERAL OBLIGATIONS LAW). THE PARTIES HEREBY IRREVOCABLY SUBMIT TO THE EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION [***] Confidential Treatment Requested 27 Source: BLOOM ENERGY CORP, DRS/A (on S-1), 3/21/2018 OF ANY STATE OR FEDERAL COURT IN NEW YORK COUNTY, NEW YORK WITH RESPECT TO ANY ACTION OR PROCEEDING ARISING OUT OF OR RELATING TO THIS AGREEMENT. EACH PARTY IRREVOCABLY AND UNCONDITIONALLY WAIVES TRIAL BY JURY IN ANY ACTION, SUIT OR PROCEEDING RELATING TO A DISPUTE AND FOR ANY COUNTERCLAIM WITH RESPECT THERETO.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 9.6 Governing Law, Jurisdiction, Venue. THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE GOVERNED BY AND INTERPRETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK WITHOUT REGARD TO CONFLICTS OF LAW PRINCIPLES (OTHER THAN SECTION 5-1401 OF THE NEW YORK GENERAL OBLIGATIONS LAW). THE PARTIES HEREBY IRREVOCABLY SUBMIT TO THE JURISDICTION OF ANY STATE OR FEDERAL COURT. EACH PARTY IRREVOCABLY AND UNCONDITIONALLY WAIVES TRIAL BY JURY IN ANY ACTION, SUIT OR PROCEEDING RELATING TO A DISPUTE AND FOR ANY COUNTERCLAIM WITH RESPECT THERETO.
perturbation.explanation: Removing "EXCLUSIVE" jurisdiction of NEW YORK COUNTY, NEW YORK gives the parties more optionality of where the jurisdiction is and makes it so it's no longer a Consumer Protection Right of "Venue". A consumer protection right is defined as a set of laws designed to ensure fair competition and the free flow of truthful information in the marketplace. Waiving the exclusive clause can make the consumer vulnerable to having to appear in an out of state court.
